Code Documentation¶

Main¶

This is the main function that controls the flow of all the other processes.

How To Use This Module¶

  1. Activate venv: source venv/bin/activate
  2. Start support services: ./start_ol_services.hs
  3. Run it: python main.py
class main.Laser_Writer[source]¶

This class calls all the necessary helper modules. Concurrently running modules are handled with pythons threading library

__init__()[source]¶

Initilise a Laser_Writer object

demo()[source]¶

There are two sections to the demo:

  1. Select and display a random tweet
  2. Directly enter a message into the command prompt

The function will start by randomly showing tweets. Hit ctrl-c to switch to keyboard promt. Hit crtl-c again to exit

start_tweet_retrieval()[source]¶

Continuously check for new tweets with the matching criteria

Args:
None
Returns:
None
write_tweet(tweet='This is the default tweet', time_display=10)[source]¶

Will send a tweet to the laser to be written

Args:
tweet: A 140 character max string to be sent to the laser
time_display: How long the tweet will be displayed. When the time runs out the thread will terminate and the function will exit.
Returns:
None
Note:
Will print out the message to be displayed.

Openlase_Driver¶

OpenLase is an open source library and toolkit for controlling laser scanners. It has an emphasis on real-time operation and integration with audio, and it uses the JACK Audio Connection Kit as a backend.

Features include:

  • Classic OpenGL-like API
  • Support for ILDA format sprites
  • SVG to ILDA converter
  • Built-in vector font
  • Realtime bitmap tracer (edge detection)
  • Python bindings
  • Video player (using the bitmap tracer)
  • Output processor GUI with perspective correction (projecting from an angle) and level controls.

More information can be found at: https://marcan.st/projects/openlase/ or https://github.com/marcan/openlase

class Openlase_Driver.Openlase_Driver[source]¶

This class is a driver to provide an easier way to access the openlase functions

get_tweet_string(tweet_words, count=-1)[source]¶

Reformats a list of words into a string

Args:
tweet_words: A list of strings that make up the full tweet
count: How many of the words are to be used for the string
Returns:
String reformatted like the original tweet
segment_message(tweet_string)[source]¶

Format the tweet so it will be properly output by the laser writer

Args:
tweet_string: string containing the message with no formatting
Returns:
list of strings that are cut to appropriate lengths
write_tweet(tweet_string, time_display)[source]¶

Displays a 140 character max message with lasers

Args:
tweet_string: String that contains the message (tweet)
time_display: How long the message will be displayed. The function will exit when the time runs out
Returns:
None
Note:
Calls openlase functions that will send the data through JACK to the laser galvos and the simulator

Laser_Format¶

Contains all the functions to format a raw text string into something that can be output by the laser writer.

Input: String Output: Double nested list of strings (one for each laser, one for each line).

Formatting that will be done:¶

  1. convert to 128bit ascii.
  2. remove hyperlinks, metions
  3. wordwrapping (split words if needed)
  4. split into one section per laser
class Laser_Format.Laser_Format[source]¶

Handles the formatting and segmentation

__init__()[source]¶

Initializes a Laser_Format object

Select_Tweet¶

Select a tweet from the pool of potential tweets based on a predetermined algorithm.
The pool of tweets are stored in output.txt in JSON format
Currently the most advanced selection method is select_random_tweet_id()
Future implementations will include more intelligent tweet selections based on a number of factors, such as:
- Location
- Time
- Subjet Matter
- Number of favorites/retweets
- Hashtags

Retrieve_Tweets¶

Twitter offers a comprehensive set of REST APIs to provide programmatic access to read and write Twitter data. More information is avaiable at the following link

Several other sources were used to write the Retrive_Tweet module:
- Tutorial: http://socialmedia-class.org/twittertutorial.html
- Python Library: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/twitter
- Search API query docs: https://dev.twitter.com/rest/public/search
class Retrieve_Tweets.Retrieve_Tweets(black_list, mention_account='@malcolm_test', retrieval_count='20', filter_='filter:safe', lang='en', tweets_filename='output.txt')[source]¶

https://dev.twitter.com/rest/public

__init__(black_list, mention_account='@malcolm_test', retrieval_count='20', filter_='filter:safe', lang='en', tweets_filename='output.txt')[source]¶

Initializes an instance of the retrieve tweets module

Args:
black_list: string containg inappropriate words that should be filtered out, add them in this format `-shit -piss -fuck -cunt -cocksucker -motherfucker`
mention_account: The account that the tweets are directed to
retrieval_count: Maximum number of tweets that will be retrieved in a single refresh
filter_: Twitters own filtering intelligence to make sure tweets are safe
lang: Language of the tweet
tweets_filename: Storage location for retrieved tweets
Returns:
None
Note:
Also takes care of the authorization
get_tweets()[source]¶

Store any tweets that match the search parameters

Args:
None
Returns:
None
Note:
- Stores discovered tweets in file determined by tweets_filename
- Prints out tweet id whenever a new tweet is found
- Successive searches will only look for tweets that have come in since the last search
